history.content: I've been struggling with this question for the past few weeks. I'm also interested in grad school for ML. After this semester I'll have finished the ol' 126, 127, 189 trilogy + math 104, and every single qualified person I've asked has told me that the courses I take should now depend on the research I choose to pursue and my interests. I guess, to get into graduate school you need to display research ability and so you should maximize around that before you apply. The other thing is probably those classes require a lot of mathematical maturity and taking them later is probably a better idea to get more out of them. I still think I'm going to (like Sahai recommended) take a few foundational courses; especially hoping there's some small chance 227B is open to ugrads next semester, + maybe EE226A.

I am interested in eventually going to grad school for ML. In @4475, Prof. Sahai mentioned that "Statistics foundations are something that you certainly have to build at some point (to have a well-rounded education in this space), so the question is when. I believe that there are good reasons that those foundations are better built when you are a graduate student." Can anyone clarify why it is better to take these statistics classes in grad school?
history.subject: Taking Classes in Undergrad vs. Grad School
